bioghist.head: Historical and Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Burke, Virginia is named after Col. Silas Burke (1796-1854) who lived in Fairfax County near the Ravensworth plantation of the Fitzhughs, the location of which today is known as the Silas Burke House. In 1854, the area became known as “Burke’s Station” after Silas Burke, then a director for the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, donated land for the right of way and a railroad station. During the Civil War, the area saw heavy action. Burke’s notable claim to fame occurred on December 28, 1862 when Confederate General J.E.B. Stuart raided Burke’s Station, seized supplies and the telegraph office, and sent a telegram to Union Quartermaster General Montgomery C. Meigs complaining of the poor quality of mules he had captured.

After the war, Burke remained a sleepy town until June 13, 1951, when the Justice Department posted public notices in the Burke post office announcing that the government condemned 4,520 acres of land in the Burke area for the new Washington airport. The citizens fought a successful battle against the airport’s construction and ultimately the government relocated the airport to Chantilly, Va where it is today known as Dulles International Airport. Since then, Burke has grown significantly with the construction of housing subdivisions and land development.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Burke, Virginia Collection consists of 0.5 linear feet and spans the years 1937-2015 consisting of reports, correspondence, newspaper clippings, newsletters, brochures, pamphlets, photocopies, framed needlework art, a commemorative pin, and a hand drawn map. Subjects include the history of Burke, Virginia, Burke Centre Conservancy, and the Copperthite Racetrack.
